Guns of Icarus is a great game in a genre that doesn't exist much anymore.  The core gameplay is simple: play with a human, AI, or mixed crew and pilot a steampunk themed airship and take on your enemies. There are 7 ships and 3 classes to choose from, so there's enough diversity in the game to keep you interested. Gamemodes are limited though; there is only 'team deathmatch' and king of the hill. Nonetheless, either game mode is fun (though most players prefer TDM) and you can play 2v2 to 4v4 matches. It is exponentially more fun to play with friends, but the community, though very small, still mostly cooperates and communicates in game. Additionally, the developers are very involved. Not many games feature events where the Dev team challenges players for prizes.  The game is full of fun waiting to be had, and at only 10 dollars it's hard not to find a reason to buy this game. Round up 3 friends and buy this game and go have a blast.  P.S. If you are new to the game, the best strategy is to pilot a squid with 3 gunners and set each weapon to mine launcher. Trust me, it works every time.

Very fun and engrossing action/strategy. Airship battles set in a steampunk atmosphere. Everything relies on your team working together which is made up of specialized members, ie unique classes/equipment loadouts which can be customized. There is absolutely no 'rambo'ing' in the game. There are no individual stats displayed at the end of each round, although they are tracked so you can review them yourself, and do contribute to your character leveling up. Leveling your character confers no in-game bonus, but does serve as an indicator of how much experience you have playing the game. However, a team of veterans who do not pull together with their ship can easily be out-maneuvered and overpowered by a team of noobs who are actually working together, albeit even without a great understanding of how the game works. This is accomplished by built in voice support which automatically moves you to channels for the game lobby and your ship, once the action starts. The captains of the ships can also use a separate channel to plan strategy amongst themselves before handing out orders to their crew. That's what makes it such an interesting dynamic. The ships are competing, not the individuals. The crews are completing, not the individuals that make them up. It is also nice to play a game where the devs and mods play often and are available for questions. They've even added a couple new maps since I started playing a few weeks ago.

An amazing example of alternitive online gaming. Steampunk airship naval style battles.   Matchmade with four crew per ship, one human captain is required per ship but bots will fill empty crew slots, allowing for one player per ship. Custimization boasts a variety of ships each offering a differnt play style, alongside class abilities and selectable deck guns. The combat is a mix of shooting the main weapons and maintaining the ship, with weapons manned by gunners and engineers running between engines and ballons. Each of the three classes has equipable gear and clothing, however leveling is removed to allow even fighting between any player, skill instead is what you gain in battle.   The health of the ship comes down to armour, covering the bear hull and auxillary systems needed to maintain flight. Each can be independantly targeted and destroyed, or set aflame, requiring any available crew to repair, all come with a basic repair, engineers specializing.   A great game  There is a rumored PvE in the works potentially containin a Co-op Campaign

Short version: A genre busting gem with cool gameplay and friendly community.  Long version:  It's kind of hard to find a place to start when talking about this game because there really is nothing else like it out there. Its like the best parts of some games combined with new ideas to make a new experience that for once is fresh and new. In a way it a is a class based, first person game with a third person option. Now when I say first person, and class based most would think TF2, and that isnt too bad of a frame of reference, except instead of mercs, each class has a different job on a flying steampunk battle ship. There is the gunner, whose main job is to man the ships gun turrets and fire at the other ships while loading up the guns with special ammo, the engineer who races around the ship keeping everything working while you are being fired at with various tools while buffing certain components, and the pilot whose job it is to control the ship and make sure the gunner can do their job properly. Each class is vital, but also not locked into their roles either, an engineer that doesnt need to make repairs can hop on a turret and fire or even take the helm if the pilot for whatever reason cant, a gunner can aid in repairs and naturally can repair their own guns, a pilot can let go of the helm and help out the engineers during a lull in the action. It's a game where teamwork and smarts take priority over mashing a button.   The game also has a cash shop in it, yes I heard the groans that coe when the word cash and shop are next to each other and can sense some worrying about it being pay to win, well guess what it isnt like that. The cash shop is purely for customization items for your character and ship. and if you dont want to pay for that kind of thing a lot can be obtained through ranking up via achievments. As for ships and weapons, guess what all are available to everyone from the get go, though novice players are limited since they are still learning the game.   It's unique, it has a lot of good ideas behind it, it has a welcoming community and most imortantly, it's fun! Go and get it already!

I sight an enemy of the port. The hull of my foe emerges from the clouds and I quickly yell to the crew, things just got interesting. I set a new heading and were off, were still out of range, the gunners tense up waiting for the right moment to fire. The engineers run around the ship buffing the weapons. Then all hell breaks loose, we exchange fire while a second hostile emerges from the clouds on our starboard side, peppering us with a devastating barrage. The prow guns are reloaded and we fire again, our baloon is hit, the port gun is damaged and the engine is on fire. I order the starboard guns to manned and I sweep by the enemy pouring red hot death into the their flank and quickly pull our ship up and around before we get blown to bits. The situatuon becomes desprate as we are pounded by combined fire from both hostiles. At the last second our ally swoops in and under combined fire we slay our first ship. The last enemy turns and fires on my ally ripping them to shreds and destroying them. My ship can hardly fly, the baloon is damaged, my guns are out, and the our hull is falling apart, I turn to my engineer and say 'this is gunna be a bumby ride'. I turn on the moonshine and rocket forward towards my last enemy. The crew is scrambling to maintain our crippled engines as the enemy launches a salvo at us. Moments from impact I switch to Impact Bumpers and slam into the foe, shattering them like a light bulb under a sledge hammer. A narrow victory, but a victory all the same!  tl;dr This game is EPIC! Get it.

Guns of Icarus is a multiplayer team game where crews engage in aerial dogfights in order to be victorious as a team.  I was given this game by a friend in the recent autumn sale, but I had seen it before and had some intrest in it, but not enough to want to buy it outright. However playing it with my friends was a very enjoyable experience and it constantly feels challenging. The exsistence of 3 class groups means each member of a crew is equally as needed, so nobody can outshine the rest of the team, meaning team work feels rewarding and substantial. Furthermore the skill of the online community is so that there is enough novice players to start out fighting against, but also a large number of skilled crews who create very difficult and exciting matches. Also, the number of ships and weapons available mean customisation to your team's strengths is viable.  A few problems though; the game is no-where nearly as fun if you dont play with friends, or with people with a microphone. Nothing is worse than sitting in a crew where no one is communication and everyone is doing their own thing. Also, some of the avatar customisation options and lore seem a bit pointless, as they are unused in the game itself, but that is only a minor flaw.  Overall, having played the game, I would buy this game at full price, but only if I had friends to play it with. The 4-pack is definately a good idea if youre looking to play regularly. Find some friends, and spend a good few hours getting you and your 'crew' up to speed, and you'll have a great time :)

Holy crap this game is fun! What a surprise. The game is essentially squad-based arena play. You belong to a four-man team which consists of a pilot/captain, gunners, and engineers. Each role can do the other roles if someone drops out of play, but each role receives a special bonus to their abilities. Captains gain special piloting skills, gunners do better at gunning, and engineers repair things that break or catch fire on the ship (as well as buff equipment temporarily). The ships in the game are all steampunk style, so think big hot air balloons with propellors and gears. Very cool. In addition, when the game is playing, you run around the ship. Some ships will have 7 guns, so if the captain tells you to run to port side, everyone scrambles to port side to fire cannons, gatling guns, sniper cannons, flamethrowers, or whatever other types of cool guns they've decided to place on their ships. If the ship catches fire, everyone has to start putting out fires. Your balloons can be deflated/destroyed and you must fix those or you just sink to the ground. Your propellors can get knocked out so you can adjust lift, but no forward or rear projection. Settings are varied, but often have canyons or skyscrapers or giant dust clouds, so tactical manuevering comes into play.  Simply put, this is an amazing game. The graphics are 8ish/10, but the gameplay is incredibly fun. What an invigorating game. Love it. A+

Does the lack of teamwork in your FPS/MMO community leave you hot under the collar? Than let off some steam with this aeronautical adventure.   In Guns of Icarus you get to be a pilot, gunner or engineer on an airship with three other cog-loving crew members. Whether you are manically mending your mechanized lifeboat, fearsomely firing from forward cannons or suavely swerving through ships and spires this game always has you bracing for impact.   At the core of this game is the crew mentality. Since all classes can man a gun, repair a balloon or take helm (although each class is better at its given task), you are often switching around or collaborating efforts to keep your ship afloat. Every ship's crew has a captain who not only guides his crew but strategies with other captains. Crew members in turn help keep captains and their mates apprised of the situation with information such as damage reports, spotted enemy ships and triumphant cheers as the enemy bursts apart. This lends to both an immersive gameplay experience and one of the best communities in gaming.

The other three crew can either be engineers or gunners and have many fixing tools or a variety of bullets.   Community is STRONG and communication is great. Play a while, friend some folks, and soon everyone knows your name. Very friendly folks in a mostly positive and constructive environment. Some of the best times I've had were just chit chatting in the lobbies.  GET THE FOURPACK. WRECK STUFF WITH FRIENDS AND MEET NEW PEOPLE. BE THE CREW OF A BEASTLY STEAMPUNK WAR ZEPPELIN.

This is a great game. I could go on and on. Lets go over the pros and cons.  Pros:  1: Great team-based gameplay. I mean, this almost rivals Counter Strike's teamplay. You can't 'Carry' your team like in Counter Strike. Everyone on your team has to be good and work together to win.  2: Amazing netcode. I got put into a European server with 117 ping. In Counter Strike, there would be a noticeable delay when you get a kill, buy weapons, etc. This? I didn't even remember that I had 110 ping. That's impressive. 3: Nice matchmaking. This game matchmaking is great, maybe even better then CS's. Fast queue times(even though there is only 800 playing right now)and, you get to pick your preferred server. And if you get put into a different server, you won't notice because the netcode is so good. And CS's matchmaking also isn't that good because there are a ton of hackers. This game? None.  Cons:  1: Sometimes, the matchmaking puts you with a couple of bots. That can be annoying.  9.5/10

I invested a little time in playing this game by now (about 800 hours in three months is a little, right? right?), so...I guess it's time to say a few words about it. I'll make it quick: One of the greatest ♥♥♥♥in games ever. No, scratch that. THE greatest ♥♥♥♥in game ever. So, just buy it.   If you like teamplay, commuicating with your teammates, and an awesome community, this game means endless hours of fun for you. You have a huge variety of ships and guns, which allows for a lot of customization. This game can be everything.  Quick, when your team is just working together much better then the enemys. Or the other way round.  Slow, sometimes boring, when your enemy is hiding (tho it's always ♥♥♥♥in great to punish him for that, once you find him). Intense, when you're at the edge of dying, getting tripple teamed, your allies are dead, but your crew somehow manages to keep you alive. Or if it's just a really close game, a tie, match point for both teams, both of them charge, and suddenly: endscreen, and for a few seconds you don`t even know who won. Incredibly funny, if you just play with the right people. When you're joking around, while waiting for the game to start.  So...yeah, just buy it. And tell your friends to buy it as well. Tell everyone.

The game is pretty straight forward- work with your crew/ team to completely blow up the enemy/ win an objective. The community is genuinely really friendly and we could really use more players! :D  Great core gameplay and atmosphere that combine to make a simply great game! I love the steampunk feel and the design is really good. I love the soundtrack- it really fits the style of a great, adventurous, epic steampunk world- adding to the feel of the game; and also makes me think of Disney's Atlantis- which was kinda steampunk itself.  The different ships are really creative and add interesting tactics to every match- every ship has strenghts and weaknesses! And there is no one ship that is better- I'd say this game is VERY balanced and new players can pick it up pretty quickly. 3 roles: Gunner- just need to aim good and occasionally help the engineers repair. Engineer- repair stuff by whacking it!- a bit more stressful - especially in the middle of a blitzing fight. Pilot/ Captain- Much more skill required as you need to know strenghts of your ship and position well according to them.  Team work is essential but like I said- the community is really friendly!!! The maps are fun- I like the desert maps best.  Lots of features in the gameplay/ menu that add a lot more to the game, but are not that difficult to learn.   Awesome game! Simple, fun, and a great design, feel and community! I really recommend this game!

Really fun game. I didn't have any idea what I was doing at first and loved it, then once I actually figured out how to play, I loved it even more. You have 3 classes in this game: gunner, pilot, and engineer. The gunner gets more ammo types than any of the other classes, the engineer gets more repair and buff tools, and the pilot gets the most piloting skills (abilities they can activate while flying that have special effects, such as buffing the ship but damaging it or creating a giant smoke cloud). There are a fair variety of weapons for your ship like gattling guns, shotguns, sniping guns, medium-range flak cannons, and flamethrowers. Each has its advantages and disadvantages. Finding the right combo of gun and ammo type can be devastating to enemies.  All in all this game is pretty awesome, though it can be a bit unstable and crash sometimes (for me at least).

Guns of Icarus is an exciting and compelling multiple crew naval-type game involving zepplins.  You heard that right.  For a long time my friends and I were looking for a game that we could get together on the same ship, man the various ship components involved in running them, and do battle against other fully crewed and combat-ready vessels. We found it with Guns of Icarus.  This game has a dynamic physics engine and map design that allows for serious tactics to be used when playing in either public or competitive league matches. It has ships of various sizes, armament and manuevering capabilities, and is some of the most fun I have ever had playing a competitive game.  Get a squad up, choose your ship and get airborne!

Guns of Icarus; A game of strategy, steampunkness, and synergy (when your lucky)  10/10 would pilot again.

Guns of Icarus is a first-person Aircarft-shooting simulator. It was published 2012 by Muse.  It's a multiplayer-only game.  What's good? -Nice community (probabaly the best you ever met) -Epic feeling included -Challenging -AIRSHIPS -Stratigic -Teamwork required -Good controles -Lots of fun -Ok graphics -Extremly handsome Tip Box  What's not so great? -Not alot of players online -Long waiting time for matchs -Sometimes a bit laggy  Worth knowing/tipps -Get some friends to play -Is still being patched (not always for the better, for example the server list was removed for an auto-matchmaking) -There are microtransactions, however, just for cosmetics  What's the game about? -Shoot other Airships with guns -There are 3 classes (Gunner/Engenieer/Captain) and 7 shiptypes with different specifics (for example speed/armor/etc.) and different maps. Every map has different structures, effects/etc., for example clouds, broken ships, cliffs, etc. -Every class has different effects, for example, the gunners can use different ammos to set ships on fire, more damage for hulls, armor etc.  All in all: 9/10 get it if you enjoy challenges and team-based shooters, but get freinds. Best would be to pick it up during a sale with 3 extra copies.  BxP

Great game overall. It's obvious that the Devs have put countless hours into their product, and continue to do so to ensure the experience is great for their players, but the Devs also promote the community's own creativity and sponsor the cream of the crop in terms of interesting and inspired designs. You do not ave to pay money to win at the game, which is a refreshing change in today's indie market. Instead, purchases are purely for cosmetic purposes.  If you enjoy the Steampunk genre and a combat system that encourages creativity, teamwork and brave decisions, this is the game for you!  Although, it has to be said that the community can be TOXIC. There is obviously an elitist mentality among some of the veteran players towards newer players who are still trying to learn, and at times ruins the experience for newbies and veterans alike. That doesn't mean that some of the newer folk aren't a toxic bunch on their own. Some days the lobbies get so loud and full of all manner of unpleasantries that it becomes a chore to find an actual match.

EDIT: The developers reverted the most severe changes within a few days of release. New review will be forthcoming as time permits.  =================================================================  This used to be a great game. Unfortunately, the last update has completely changed the core mechanics of the game in such a way as to make the game unplayable if you don't have at least 5 friends you consistently play with at any given time.  Matches are now decided purely by ally and crew skill level. While there used to be some margin for error in which a good pilot could recover from a bad situation and/or a relatively poor crew, there is now no margin at all. Ships routinely go down in two salvos from an enemy vessel with no hope of escape. Being ambushed is fatal 100% of the time.  The only way to have a nonzero chance of winning a round is to be willing to stack your side of the lobby with highly experienced players. This is why I mentioned at least 5 friends above; if you start a match with AI crew anywhere on your team you will get a new player or two join during the match and you will die. There is no player kick feature, so all it takes is one new player on your team and you need to start all over again in a new lobby, hoping again to get all high level players just to have a *chance* at actually winning. To add insult to injury, the playerbase is so small that each round of lobby stacking can take 30 minutes or more, just to have a new player join at the last minute and force a restart. This frequently leads to a.) playing anyway and predictably losing or b.) not playing at all. I have stopped playing GoIO over this; waiting 45 minutes in Lobbies of Icarus for a 5 minute match has zero appeal. Established competitive clans regularly use this major game flaw to pubstomp casual players.  The game fundamentally was designed around three distinct types of player, Captain, Engineer, and Gunner, each with its own unlockable cosmetic items and achievements. These items, if not unlocked, are for sale for real world currency in Muse's online store. The recent update has made it so that no one will fly with Gunner class players on their ships. On the surface, this looks like a greedy move from the game developers to effectively lock 1/3 of the unlockable items and force people to spend money on them instead.  Maps and gametypes are stale, gameplay becomes more mundane and boring with each patch from the developers (around 6 - 12 months between patches). Focus seems to be on the 'Lobbies of Icaus' metagame, with matches frequently decided in the lobby before the skirmish even starts. Game also appears to be going through some kind of identity crisis with the introduction of fixed-wing WWII-style airplanes in Adventure mode (remember this was supposed to be a steampunk alternate world with airships, but now we also have airplanes?!).  While I heartily enjoyed the old game, this new one is a complete waste of time. Don't waste your money on it too!

I had to re-write my review in the light of the recent Alliance DLC, as Guns of Icarus Online takes a second life.  Quick recap: this great-looking and great-sounding game is about piloting, gunning and repairing dieselpunk airships dukeing it out in a post-apocalyptic, war-thorn land, using crazy-♥♥♥♥♥ weaponry. It is high-adrenaline, and very-much team-based rather than true PvP: It is also fair; beginners like veterans have the very same skills and choices.  It is NOT a dogfighting airgame, and it is NOT a FPS: It is closer to a moving Tower Defense kind of game. It may seem ponderous at the beginning, but once the ennemy is sighted it gets intense real fast, and in these times, crew cohesion and fleet tactics will make the difference. A mike is strongly suggested.  The biggest beef I had with the game was its exclusive PvP nature - and it latest matchmaking habits. But since Alliance got released, it's a whole new game as player fleets face waves of PvE challenges, with new airships and more. There is a world, or franchise building itself up around these fantastic machines, and Alliance is the first step towards it. I definitely want more of it. How many steampunk games are there on Steam?  Just buy the game, even if you are not a ship/dieselpunk/fighting games adept: it is cheap (the online store only sells cosmetic add-ons that have no impact on one's performence), the community is gentlemanly and the developpers keep an ear to the ground with feedback, events and gifts.  Best gaming value on Steam, IMHO. And it's an Indie.

There are few games out there that can capture the same variety of emotions and experiences as those that can be found in Guns of Icarus. You can fall into the manic, terror-fueled left-clicking maddness of immenent doom, when you see your screen full of red flashing icons indicating two dozen things that need to be immediately fixed, and all you have is your wrench, your hammer, and the hope that your captain knows what he's doing. You can enjoy the slow build of anticipation as you hunt your as-yet unrevealed foe, mixed with the awe-inspiring serenity of the landscapes that you pass under, over and between on your way. You can feel the unrivaled sense of superiority and swashbuckling derring-do as you fly your airship head-on into your enemy, guns blazing, orders cutting through the air with all the vim and urgency of the most confident of crack military commanders. You can experience those moments when your captain lines you up the sweetest shot with the flamethrower you've ever had, and you feel neither remorse, nor pity for the crew opposite, but a real glee as you cook their ship around them like a Tennasee barbecue. You can feel a sense of accomplishment when you suddenly realize how well you and your fellow teammates are behaving, strategically, and how well it's working, and how that match seems so laughably easy that you cannot help but grin. And then there is the full, complete joy of rattling through a pitched battle of heavy fighting, where both you and your opponent are so thouroughly even and so nearly licked, but you pull out the one maneuver they weren't expecting, and come out on top. With everyone breathing a glad sigh of relief for just one mutual moment of perfect happiness before turning towards the wreckage of the ship and getting it back in order.  This is quite simply the ultimate game for a bunch of buddies who just want to get together and prove their teamworking skills over all others.
